entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 19, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Boston Red Sox @ Tampa Bay Rays, 4:35p

Summary

Top gNERD on the slate, and it earns it: ace-level Garrett Crochet (pNERD 12.26, xFIP- 62) squares off with a restored Drew Rasmussen at the Raysâ temporary outdoor digs, where Bostonâs elite bullpen meets Tampa Bayâs track team. If you like whiffs plus stolen-base chaos with late-inning leverage, this one checks every box. By our model this gameâs gNERD is 17.32, the dayâs highest and well above the historical 95th percentile, and the matchup brings real storylines with it: Crochet, now locked up long-term in Boston, has paired upper-90s heat with strike- and swing-miss rates that scream ace; Rasmussen, back from his internal-brace comeback and under a two-year deal, has been efficient more than flashy. With Sox tNERD strength coming from defense and a top-shelf bullpen, the Raysâ counter is speed; theyâve been swiping bags in bunches and just rode Chandler Simpson (and steady Yandy DÃ­az) in a shutout of Toronto. The venue twist matters, too: Tampa Bay is hosting at George M. Steinbrenner Field this season, adding some outdoor variability to a club built on run prevention and legs.

(A model from OpenAI generated the above text using instructions, the NERD scores, and these sources: 1, 2, 3.)

Milwaukee Brewers @ St. Louis Cardinals, 5:15p

Summary

Triple-digits versus guile: Jacob Misiorowski, the rookie who no-hit St. Louis for five innings in his debut, squares off again with Sonny Gray, who just punched out eight Brewers last week.
Milwaukeeâs sprint toward the division flag meets a shorthanded Cardinals lineup, with Willson Contreras done for the year.

At a gNERD of 15.80, this lands above the 95th percentile of historical games and near the top of todayâs slate, and the ingredients check out: a high-octane pNERD duel (Misiorowski 10.21; Gray 6.97) plus a large tNERD edge for Milwaukee (9.72 to 4.69). Misiorowskiâs appeal is obviousâhe averages 99-plus with top-of-era perceived velocity (fastball 101.3 mph; a slider that looks like mid-90s), which plays beautifully against a St. Louis offense thatâs been thinning and underperforming. Gray isnât just âveteran savvyâ; his underlying run estimators have outpaced the surface, and he just held Milwaukee to two runs over five in their latest meeting, giving this real counterpunch potential. Add Milwaukeeâs elite baserunning and deep bullpen (both strong tNERD components) against a Cards club trying to manufacture runs, and the watchability case is strong: power stuff, contrasting styles, and stakes. If you like velocity art, Misiorowski alone is worth the click.

(A model from OpenAI generated the above text using instructions, the NERD scores, and these sources: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.)

Seattle Mariners @ Houston Astros, 5:10p

Summary

High gNERD and real stakes: two power righties with strong pNERDs square off to break an AL West tie. Bryan Woo arrives off a career-best 13-K start, while Hunter Brown has been dealing in September, making this a pitching-forward watch.

At 13.62, this game grades in the top decile of historic gNERD and well above todayâs average, driven by both armsâ xFIP- (Woo 80, Brown 76) and upper-90s velocity that should keep whiffs and called strikes flowing even if pace isnât brisk. The watchability hook is simple: elite run prevention deciding a division race thatâs currently level, with Houston missing Yordan Alvarez (ankle), thinning the lineup against Wooâs splitter/sinker mix.

Brownâs recent form (6.2 IP, 2 ER vs. ATL; 1.42 September ERA) supports the pNERD, and Houstonâs defense/bullpen combo has carried weight all year, so every baserunner matters. Seattle brings punch (13 HR in its last 10) and enough bullpen to shorten the game if Woo hands off cleanly.

Translation: a top-tier gNERD duel with playoff leverage, premium stuff on both sides, and contrasting support systemsâAstrosâ gloves and pen vs. Seattleâs powerâtilting each pitch into event television.

Cleveland Guardians @ Minnesota Twins, 5:10p

Summary

Rookie Parker Messickâs quick pace and bat-dulling run prevention (xFIP- 79) meets Pablo LÃ³pezâs postâIL precision, so this grades as appointment pitching, not background noise. With a 13.21 gNERDâupper quartile by the historical distributionâplus Clevelandâs runâprevention machine and a Twins lineup thatâs been lifting the ball, itâs a highâpriority watch.

Messick vs. LÃ³pez is the listed matchup, and the rookie has kept damage to one earned run or fewer in four of his first five MLB starts, which backs his strong pNERD (8.54) and watchable tempo. LÃ³pez (pNERD 5.29) was activated Sept. 5 from a teresâmajor strain and should bring command and a deep changeup/fastball mix; heâs handled Cleveland reasonably well across prior meetings.

Clevelandâs appeal isnât offense; itâs how they catch it and finish gamesârecently ranking near the top by bullpen FIP and grading well defensivelyâso a tight, lowâmistake script is very much in play. Minnesota boosts the entertainment quotient with 17 homers over its last 10 games.

If you want stakes with your stuff+, Clevelandâs surge has them within 4.5 of the AL Central lead and 2.5 of a Wild Card as of Sept. 18, while Minnesota leans on LÃ³pezâs return to stabilize the staff. That mix, plus contrasting pNERDs (Messick 8.54; LÃ³pez 5.29), justifies the lofty gNERD.

Chicago Cubs @ Cincinnati Reds, 3:40p

Summary

Playoff math meets lefty craft: the clinched-but-still-hungry Cubs send Shota Imanaga into Great American while the Reds, two back in the wild-card chase, counter with Nick Lodoloâs sturdier underlying profile. After Hunter Greeneâs one-hit opener, another tight, low-scoring tilt is very much on the table.

At 11.97, this gameâs gNERD sits comfortably above todayâs average, mostly because Chicagoâs top-tier tNERD (barrels, clean defense, aggressive baserunning) promises action even when the ball isnât clearing fences, while Cincinnatiâs offense has been the less entertaining partner in this dance. Imanagaâs pNERD is modest: he fills the zone, but the xFIP- is a tick worse than league (106) and the long ball has been the taxâ26 homers allowed and counting. Lodoloâs pNERD is stronger, with a better xFIP- (91), and he held the Cubs to one run over 6.1 the last time he saw them.

Context helps: the Cubs already punched their ticket, but the Reds are still leaning on their arms to stay in the bracket picture; that raises the pitch-by-pitch urgency, if not the raw fireworks. If you like taut lefty-versus-lefty chess with elite gloves and opportunistic baserunning, this is worth a primary screen.

New York Yankees @ Baltimore Orioles, 4:05p

Summary

A strike-throwing lefty on a heater vs. MLBâs barrel kings: Trevor Rogers against the Yankees is a clean watchability hook. At gNERD 11.8âabove todayâs average and the historical medianâthis is one of the dayâs better bets.

Rogers (pNERD 8.08) has leaned on a five-pitch mix and elite zone rates, with hitters flailing at his four-seam/change and a new sweeper during a months-long run. Baltimoreâs lineup is lighter with Adley Rutschman on the IL, so rookie Samuel Basalloâs bat/catch combo matters more. New Yorkâs big tNERD (7.98) is powered by top-tier barrels, and the Yankees are still chasing the division after a 7-0 opener. Will Warren (pNERD 4.47) is more volatile, but he doesnât have to be perfect in a lineup built to punish mistakes. The Oriolesâ lower tNERD (3.06) and iffy defense/pen leave a thin margin if Rogers blinks; if he shoves, we get a crisp duel. Probable: Warren vs. Rogers.

Washington Nationals @ New York Mets, 4:10p

Summary

Mets-heavy watchability, rookie-flavored volatility. Brandon Sproatâs power intro (no-hit bid in his debut, six crisp in his Citi opener) meets Nationals call-up Andrew Alvarez, who debuted with five scoreless and followed with six more, so the unknowns are actually the draw.

With a gNERD of 11.38, the tilt rides New Yorkâs top-of-today tNERD: the Mets bring barrels, baserunning and a broadcast that flat-out plays, while Washingtonâs tNERD lagâdragged by defense and a shaky penâmakes any deficit feel bigger. Sproatâs stuff (upperâ90s fastball with a sweeper/sinker mix) has looked like a major-league kit; tiny-sample indicators put him around a 3.5 xFIP, whereas Alvarezâs sterling run prevention so far comes with a ~4.5 xFIP flag, i.e., regression risk and ball-in-play intrigue. Add a small wrinkle: the Mets just shelved high-leverage arm Reed Garrett, nudging late-inning chaos probability upward.

Net: above the daily median and worth your time for two reasonsâthe Metsâ bat/pen/broadcast trifecta and the rookie-on-rookie texture. If youâre sorting the slate, this is a sensible priority: New Yorkâs offense tests a lefty with thin MLB track record, while Sproatâs âis this real?â stuff-chase gets another data point.

Philadelphia Phillies @ Arizona Diamondbacks, 6:40p

Summary

Two potent lineups, one shaky bullpen, and a contactâfriendly mound matchup make this a batsâfirst watch. If Philadelphia piggybacks Taijuan Walker with Walker Buehler as reported, the floor rises a touch, but Arizonaâs wildâcard chase is the real hook.

With a gNERD of 10.27, this sits near the middle of todayâs slate but above the historic median; the edge comes from offense and context, not aces. Philadelphiaâs tNERD (8.61) reflects real punch, and the Dâbacks have been a topâfive runâscoring club with topâfive homeârun totals, so balls should fly at Chase. Arizonaâs bullpen has been a sinkhole by ERA and WPA, an entertainment boon late if this stays close.

On the hill, Walkerâs low pNERD (2.03) matches the inputs: a belowâaverage xFIPâ (113) and minimal whiffs; Nelson (pNERD 4.82) brings leagueâaverage run prevention under the hood (xFIPâ ~98) with firm velocity, and heâs been on a run of quality starts. The matchup details are fun: Bryce Harper is 4âforâ9 with a homer off Nelson, and the Philliesâ clinch means lineup depth and lateâinning offense are squarely in play.

Net: expect action more than artistryâlong flies, leveragey bullpen theater, and stakes that matter in September.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 18, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Castillo just logged six strong frames with five Ks in his last turn, and the stakes are real after Seattleâs long streak ended here and the Astros inched ahead in the West. Kolek, acquired at the deadline and fresh from a solid debut month, remains the wild card.

Probables: Castillo vs. Kolek; KC promoted him after the trade, and heâs been serviceable since.

gNERD 7.09 sits at the floor of todayâs range, and the culprit is a lopsided tNERD split (MIA 5.14 vs. COL -0.97) and merely middling pNERDs (Alcantara 5.60; Tanner Gordon 4.41). Alcantaraâs stuff remains loud (97.4 mph) and his xFIP- sits near league average (102), and heâs fresh off 7 innings and 8 Ks against Detroit as he continues the first full season after Tommy John, a comeback thatâs a storyline unto itself. Gordonâs profile is more contact-prone (xFIP- ~102), but he did just spin six innings of one-run ball in San Diego. Coloradoâs watchability drag is real: bottom-of-MLB run prevention and a staff that issues free passes, a combination that fueled yet another loss and a 41-111 mark. If you tune in, youâre betting on Alcantaraâs velocity playing up at altitude and on Coorsâ run environment to keep the entertainment quotient respectable despite the numbers.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 17, 2025
entry.content:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Philadelphia Phillies @ Los Angeles Dodgers, 7:10p

Summary

Two premium lefties and a lot of star wattage make this the game to prioritize. With a gNERD of 16.47âthe top mark on todayâs slateâthis one pairs strikeout stuff with lineups that punish mistakes. Luzardo arrives sizzling after retiring 22 straight in his last start (10 K, 0 BB), while Snellâs previous turn featured 11 strikeouts over six scoreless; thatâs bona fide swing-and-miss fuel for both sides. The series has already had a neon sign over itâShohei Ohtani threw five no-hit innings and clubbed his 50th homerâthough the Dodgersâ bullpen then yielded nine runs, a reminder that late innings wonât be boring. On the numbers, both pNERDs (Luzardo 9.39, Snell 7.62) sit well above todayâs pitching average, and the team mix is lively: Phillyâs bats/baserunning pop, L.A.âs power and relief corps usually travel. Phillies are slightly dinged without Trea Turner (hamstring), and the Dodgers remain thin at catcher with Will Smith on the IL. Postseason positioning is very much in play, so expect urgency to match the stuff.

San Diego Padres @ New York Mets, 4:10p

Summary

Playoff stakes, barrel bats, and a pair of better-than-average run preventers push this gNERD 15.37 matchup near the top of the watchability board. New York just tightened the wild-card race with four homers in the opener, so tonightâs PivettaâPeterson tilt should actually hinge on whose âcontact management planâ holds up.

San Diegoâs case is twofold: a bullpen that rates as one of the big watch-drivers in tNERD and Nick Pivettaâs rebrand into a bat-missing, xFIP-friendly adult; heâs held opponents to a sub-.200 average this season and could become just the fourth qualified Padre to do so, and he spun seven scoreless his last time out before the relievers blinked. Thatâs pNERD 5.46 with a tidy 91 xFIP- backed by a relief corps that usually shortens games.

On the other side, the Mets own todayâs top tNERD thanks to a barrel-happy lineup that just went deep with Brett Baty, Francisco Lindor, Pete Alonso, and Cedric Mullins, while David Petersonâs profile (pNERD 5.98, xFIP- 87) and strong Citi Field ledger give New York a viable run-prevention counter.

Net-net: elite team watchability (NYM 11.74; SD 7.56), average-plus starters, and real stakes make this one worth your primary screenâeven if last nightâs long balls donât predict tonightâs outcomes.

Toronto Blue Jays @ Tampa Bay Rays, 4:05p

Summary

A topâshelf gNERD (14.68) meets timely stakes: Gausmanâs rebound form vs. rookie Seymourâs whiffs and fast tempo, with Toronto tightening its AL East grip while Tampa stirs trouble on the bases. After two taut, reviewâspiced finishes in this series, this one has âstick around to the last pitchâ written on it.

The model gives Seymour the edge (pNERD 8.15 to 5.82), and his runâprevention inputs fit that: an 82 xFIPâ, solid swingâandâmiss, and a brisk pace that keeps the camera cutting; heâs also handled lefties well, and flashed 8âK, scorelessâstart upside since his callâup. Gausman counters with aboveâaverage contact suppression (xFIPâ 90) and, lately, results to matchâthe twoâhit, 9âK shutout last week was a âyep, still that guyâ reminder. Even with Bo Bichette sidelined for the rest of the regular season, Torontoâs lineup has stayed lively and Springerâs been in the middle of it during a current roll.

Stylistically, this pairs the Jaysâ elite defense with the Raysâ highâoctane running and solid lateâgame pen, the kind of contrast that spikes watchability even before the splitters start diving. With confirmed probables Gausman vs. Seymour and a division leader trying to bank every edge, this sits near the top of todayâs slate by both numbers and narrative.

Los Angeles Angels @ Milwaukee Brewers, 4:40p

Summary

Two high-pNERD arms and one very clear imbalance: Woodruffâs comeback form and Milwaukeeâs elite run-prevention machine versus Sorianoâs power sinker backed by one of baseballâs shakiest defenses. As a watch, this rates near the top of todayâs slate (gNERD 13.17), with the Brewersâ playoff-chasing buzz turning a strong pitching matchup into must-sample viewing.

Soriano (pNERD 8.0) brings 96â97 with heavy sink and grounders, more whiffs than punchouts by design; that works better when the gloves behind him cooperate, which the Angelsâ havenâtâStatcast pegs them at the bottom by OAA, a bad fit for a contact-heavy plan. Woodruff (pNERD 7.2) has looked like, well, Woodruff again after his July 6 return from shoulder surgery, missing bats and limiting damage while fueling the Brewersâ best-in-MLB surge.

The team split here is stark: Milwaukeeâs top-tier bullpen and aggressive baserunning (double-digit BsR) tilt late innings their way, while the Angelsâ bullpen/defense drag their tNERD down near the floor. And the backdrop matters: the Brewers already clinched and are jockeying for the top seed, and they just opened this series by thumping the Angels behind Freddy Peralta.

Net: a legitimate pitcher-forward watchâespecially earlyâwhere Milwaukeeâs run game and pen raise the entertainment ceiling if Woodruff and Soriano trade zeros.

If youâre triaging the slate, a gNERD of 11.95âabove todayâs average and near the historic 75th percentileâplus a genuine comeback storyline makes this appointment viewing. Raleigh snapped Mickey Mantleâs record and Seattle pushed its win streak to 10 in the series opener, and they currently sit atop the AL West, so the stakes (and swings) are loud. Ragans is making his first big-league start since June 5 after a rotator-cuff strain; he carved in rehab and may be capped around 70â80 pitches, but his pNERD components (xFIP- 60, plus whiffs and midâ90s heat) still scream watchability. On the other side, Bryce Millerâs pNERD (3.20) trails, yet heâs fresh off a careerâhigh 11 Ks, the kind of volatility that can spike a gameâs fun even if his xFIP- sits on the wrong side of average. Baltimore Orioles @ Chicago White Sox, 11:10a

Summary

Todayâs gNERD bottoms out at 5.75, but thereâs just enough novelty and potential chaos to justify a strategic channel-flip. Tyler Wellsâ third start back from elbow surgery squares off with MartÃ­n PÃ©rezâs contact-first craft while Baltimoreâs kids keep auditioning and Chicago tries to stop the bleeding.

Relative to todayâs slate, this is a low-watchability matchup: weak average tNERD and pNERD point to modest stuff and lineups that donât consistently punish mistakes. Still, Wells has been crisp in a tiny sample, allowing a .146 opponentsâ average and a 0.60 WHIP across 11.2 innings, and the Orioles have won his first two starts back; that âcomeback curiosityâ is the main pNERD hook. Baltimore was officially eliminated from the postseason, but the youth movement remains a draw, and it just powered an 8-7 win featuring Dylan Beavers, Samuel Basallo, Gunnar Henderson, and Coby Mayo. Chicago, meanwhile, is riding a five-game skid and hands the ball to PÃ©rez, a pitch-to-contact lefty (7.2 K/9) whoâs been steady if unspectacular. If youâre here, youâre likely watching Wellsâ feel returning and Baltimoreâs prospects taking big-league reps; if not, expect some slopâChicagoâs defense and baserunning havenât helpedâand possibly late-inning wobble after the Oâs bullpen leaked last game.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 16, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Philadelphia Phillies @ Los Angeles Dodgers, 7:10p

Summary

Top watchability on the slate, and not just by gNERD: this is Ohtaniâs rare-start spectacle against a legit Cy-level SÃ¡nchez one day after Philly clinched. If you like premium stuff and playoff-caliber lineups, you wonât need the skip button.

SÃ¡nchezâs pNERD (9.33) rides an ace-ish xFIP- of 69 and above-average whiffs, with 95.4 mph playing to a compact, strike-heavy approach; that pairs neatly with a Phillies tNERD buoyed by elite baserunning and real offensive value. On the other side, Ohtaniâs pNERD tops today (11.97) on a nuclear comboâxFIP- 62, 98 mph, and big swing-missâand heâs reportedly taking this one on 10 daysâ rest, his first pitching start ever vs. the Phils.

Narratively, itâs rich: Philadelphia just took an extras tilt to clinch, and now gets the Ohtani once-a-week treatment the Dodgers have curated since his midyear return to the mound.

If thereâs a hinge, itâs contact quality and late innings: L.A.âs lineup has been thumping of late, while its bullpen has run well, which matters if Ohtaniâs workload stays short. Meanwhile the Phillies bring more speed and a top-end starter who limits damage without the gimmicks. Thatâs why this gNERD (18.84) is todayâs ceiling and well above the historical 95th percentile.

Chicago Cubs @ Pittsburgh Pirates, 3:40p

Summary

If you like premium velocity and rookie bravado, this is appointment viewing: Paul Skenesâ Cy-caliber strikeout machine meets Cade Hortonâs Rookie-of-the-Year bid. A gNERD of 15.93 puts this comfortably among the dayâs best and even above the historical 95th percentile, with star power to match.

Skenes has crossed 200 strikeouts and sits atop the NL in Ks, pairing triple-digit heat with a FIP around the midâ2s and a run of scoreless, shortened starts as the Pirates watch his workload; heâs also stacked a Modern Era franchise record for scoreless starts. Horton counters with midâ90s gas and a tighter contact profile than your typical rookie; heâs a May call-up who blanked Pittsburgh in their last meeting and, while the ERA headline pops, the truer-season signal sits closer to a midâ3s FIP. The watchability gap tilts further because Chicago brings barrels, speed, and defense (tNERD 10.24), while Pittsburghâs bats have scraped bottomâespecially versus rightiesâasking Skenes to do most of the lifting. If you need a recent snapshot, the Cubs just opened this series with a crisp 4â0, offering a bullpen that didnât wobble. In short: ace-level stuff versus a lively offense, with a poised rookie trying to steal the spotlight from the leagueâs strikeout leader.

New York Yankees @ Minnesota Twins, 4:40p

Summary

Two hard-throwing rookies plus real stakes make this one easy to prioritize. The Yankeesâ thunderous bats meet a Twins club fresh off a 7â0 blanking of New York, so thereâs both stuff and subplot.

With a gNERD of 15.32, this grades well above todayâs average and even above the 95th percentile of historical games. New Yorkâs tNERD pops because of elite barrel rate and overall batting runs, while Minnesotaâs tNERD leans on a sturdy bullpen even if the gloves and baserunning lag. On the mound, 24-year-old Cam Schlittler brings premium velocity (upperâ90s) and a betterâthanâaverage xFIP- (89); heâs been auditioning convincingly for a postseason role and has held opponents to one run or fewer in five of his past six.

Opposite him, Zebby Matthews pairs strikeâthrowing pace with a similarly strong xFIP- (86) and has been sharper at home of late, though heâs coming off a rough turn against the Angels.

Add in Aaron Judge arriving on a Player of the Week heater, and youâve got premium punch against two intriguing rookie profilesâwatchability baked in.

A playoff-tinged duel with real watchability: rookie lefty Joey Cantillo comes in off eight-plus scoreless, while former No. 1 pick Casey Mize arrives off a crisp, miss-baiting turn, and itâs first-place Detroit against a Cleveland club still chasing. At a gNERD of 13.12âwell above todayâs average and top-quartile historicallyâthe ingredients line up: two solid pNERDs, contrasting offenses, and real late-inning bite. Cantilloâs skill signal (xFIP- 88) tracks with that career-best outing; Mizeâs profile (xFIP- 95) fits his six-inning, eight-K tune-up against New York. Detroit supplies the run-scoring juice (4.9 R/G, 187 HR), while Clevelandâs attack lags (3.9 R/G, league-worst AVG), making the matchup a classic ârun prevention vs thumpâ watch. Clevelandâs defense and deep pen elevate the viewing floorâand with Emmanuel Clase still on paid leave, Cade Smith has capably handled the ninth. If thereâs chaos, itâs likely late: Detroitâs bullpen has sprung leaks of late, including an extra-innings stumble in Miami. Layer on the stakesâTigers atop the AL Central, Guardians within wild-card rangeâand this merits a spot high on your dial.

entry.content:

Philadelphia Phillies @ Los Angeles Dodgers, 7:10p

Summary

Top of todayâs watchability board: a gNERD 15.29 with star power and two pitchers whose xFIP- (both 87) says âqualityâ before the anthem. Playoff stakes sweeten itâLAâs chasing a bye while Phillyâs already in, so this series can tilt seeding.
Ranger SuÃ¡rez arrives in full grooveâone run over his last 24 inningsâand works briskly, while Emmet Sheehan brings midâ90s ride, a whiffâheavy profile, and the best pNERD on the slate; his comeback from Tommy John and recent sevenâinning gems add narrative fuel.
Lineup theater is unavoidable: Shohei Ohtani sits one swing from another 50âhomer season, with Mookie Betts scorching of late, opposite a Phillies group thatâs been launching 19 homers over its last 10 games.
The components love the watch: Philadelphiaâs high tNERD rides real skillsâplus baserunning, solid fielding, and a broadcaster boostâwhile the Dodgers counter with big barrels and a top bullpen.
Given that todayâs gNERD range tops out here, add in Sheehanâs velo/whiffs and SuÃ¡rezâs efficiency, and youâre looking at the rare game that grades out analytically and narrativelyâmustâclick before the bracket locks.

A liveâwire rookie with real bat-missing stuff meets a savvy strikeâthrower fresh off the IL, wrapped around one of baseballâs most athletic lineups. At a 13.08 gNERDâcomfortably above the historical 75th percentileâthis belongs in the dayâs upper tier of watchability. Ashcraft is the headliner: upperâ90s fastball and breaking balls that have played to a subâ3.00 FIP with just two homers allowed in roughly 58 innings, most of them short, efficient stints; the intrigue is how deep heâs allowed to go. The matchup tilts toward action because the Cubs pair topâquartile barrels with elite baserunning and plus defense, a profile that stresses young power arms as much on contact management and hold times as on pure velocity. Taillonâs pNERD is middling, but he works quickly, lands strikes, and he just returned from a groin IL stint; earlier this summer he handled Pittsburgh with 7 K in 6.1 IP. Pittsburghâs bats have been light on impact (last in MLB in homers), which nudges the watch toward Chicagoâs side. Also: the Cubs arrive off a 4â3 win keyed by a late Nico Hoerner double.

Yankees barrels vs. Twins bullpen is the hook here, with Aaron Judge stalking a fourth 50âhomer season and Simeon Woods Richardson making his first career start against New York. At a gNERD of 9.76, this is a shade below todayâs average, but it plays up because the components pull in opposite directions. The Yankeesâ strong tNERD (8.07) is powered by premium contactâan elite barrel rateâso New Yorkâs lineup drives the watchability. On the mound, Carlos RodÃ³nâs middling pNERD (4.67) masks a useful underlying: his xFIP- is better than average and heâs diversified the arsenal in 2025, adding a sinker and leaning more on the changeup per Statcast, which can neuter righty power when located. Woods Richardsonâs low pNERD (1.99) reflects a shaky xFIP-, and the data backs it: his changeup has been hammered while a nascent splitter flashes out-pitch traitsâboomâbust viewing against a patient, power-heavy offense.

Minnesotaâs tNERD lags, but a legitimately strong bullpen shortens games and adds lateâinning intrigue if theyâre close. Add Judgeâs 50âhomer watch and recent long-ball form, and youâve got a solid, if not topâshelf, pick.

Add in Rangersâ strong defense/baserunning versus Houstonâs elite bullpen and positive âluckâ signal, and youâve got a divisional grinder with clean run prevention and just enough swing-changer potential to merit attention.

Cincinnati Reds @ St. Louis Cardinals, 4:45p

Summary

Ball-in-play theater in Busch: Zack Littellâs contact-heavy, homer-prone profile runs into the Cardinalsâ glove-first identity, while both clubs still have a pulse in the NL wild-card chase. Expect more action than whiffs, and a result that swings on who handles all those balls in play.

The gNERD sits at 7.73, a tick below todayâs slate average, and the components explain why: average-ish pNERDs (Littell 4.10, Liberatore 4.03) with low swing-and-miss rates but solid strike-throwing point toward pace and traffic over strikeouts; their xFIP-s (104/106) frame both as near-league-average run preventers. Cincinnatiâs watchability leans on speed (positive baserunning) more than thump (poor barrel rate), while St. Louis brings run-saving defense and a steady bullpen.

As for storylines: the Reds just acquired Littell, whoâs limited homers better on the road since joining Cincinnati but still leads MLB in long balls allowed, which keeps volatility high; Liberatoreâs recent line includes a five-run stumble in Seattle after a midseason run of quality starts.

Injuries nudge things, too: Masyn Winnâcentral to that elite Cards defenseâis shut down, while Nolan Arenado has been working back from a shoulder strain with a target of returning around this series; the Cardsâ late-inning mix has settled with Riley OâBrien snagging saves.

Atlanta Braves @ Washington Nationals, 3:45p

Summary

Spencer Strider is the reason to sample this one; Washington counters with contact-friendly Mitchell Parker and a defense that tends to add extra outs the hard way. On the daily watchability board, this sits near the bottom, but thereâs a little prospect sheen to keep the remote from wandering.

The gNERD is a slate-low 5.24 because both teamsâ tNERDs are weak and Washingtonâs is dragged down by poor fielding and a shaky bullpen, while Striderâs above-average pNERD (5.62) is offset by Parkerâs low mark (1.76). Strider at least brings bat-missing credibility, punching out eight over six in his last turn against Chicago; Parkerâs best recent note was 7â innings of two-run ball versus Miami. Washingtonâs kids have been the draw: Daylen Lile and James Wood just helped snag a series, and even the much-maligned bullpen â still carrying an MLB-worst ERA â stitched together a late lockdown. Atlantaâs lineup is thinner without Austin Riley, who underwent season-ending core surgery, and the staff has leaked (5.40 ERA, 15 HR) over the past 10 games â factors that nudge this toward background viewing unless Strider starts spinning sliders like 2023.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 14, 2025
entry.content:

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

New York Yankees @ Boston Red Sox, 4:10p

Summary

Fenway offers a clean hook: Garrett Crochetâs whiff factory versus the Yankeesâ barrel brigade, with todayâs top gNERD saying this rivalry tilt deserves your screen. If you like elite stuff against elite contact, this is the watch.

Crochetâs pNERD-leading side of the matchup is backed by ace-level run prevention skill (FIP in the mid-2s earlier this summer) and a cutter-forward mix thatâs played against everyone, including New York; heâs already shoved against the Yankees multiple times, striking out 11 in a recent romp. Bostonâs tNERD juice also comes from a top bullpen and plus defense, which matters if Crochet hands it off after six or seven. New Yorkâs counter is Will Warren, whose cartoonish sweeper gives him puncherâs-chance whiffs, and heâs arrived at this one on a tidy 30:10 K:BB heater with six strong frames his last time out. Recent series vibes: the Yankees just took the last meeting behind Max Fried while jockeying for playoff seeding, so the stakes and noise are real. With both teams carrying above-average tNERDs and Crochet sporting todayâs premium pNERD, this rates as the dayâs clearest âdonât overthink itâ watch.

Texas Rangers @ New York Mets, 10:40a

Summary

A top-tier gNERD (15.85) meets a live-wire storyline: Mets rookie Nolan McLeanâs high-octane, quick-tempo starts collide with Juan Soto fresh off a 40âHR/30âSB milestone and a bullpen thatâs been springing leaks. If you like youth, velocity, and late-inning chaos, this rates near the top of todayâs slate. McLeanâs pNERD (10.30) is buoyed by a strong xFIP- (72), 95+ velo, and brisk pace; heâs allowed two earned or fewer in each MLB start and brings a five-pitch mix featuring a mid-80s sweeper. The Metsâ tNERD (11.61) comes from thunder (elite barrel rate) and watchable TV, and Soto just cranked No. 40 to complete the 40/30 flex. Texas isnât flashy (tNERD 5.98) but runs well and fields well, and swingman Jacob Latz has recently delivered real innings, including 5.2 scoreless vs. Milwaukee. New Yorkâs bullpen has been good by season quality but wobbly lately, coughing up a late lead to Texas amid an extended skidâcatnip for watchability even if not predictive. Injuries matter: Marcus Semien remains on the shelf (pushing depth pieces forward), and Corey Seager has missed time following an appendectomy.

Baltimore Orioles @ Toronto Blue Jays, 10:37a

Summary

Shane Bieberâs comeback tour meets a bullpen day â one ace-caliber ceiling against a whole lot of relief-roulette. Torontoâs playoff push plus last nightâs walk-off spice makes this a worthy channel-stopper.

With a gNERD of 12.73, this lands in top-quartile watchability historically, and the ingredients check out. Bieberâs pNERD (8.96) rides an excellent xFIP- (65) and brisk pace, and heâs already flashed form since returning from Tommy John and a July trade â nine strikeouts, zero walks in his Blue Jays debut, followed by two more starts to stretch out. Toronto brings a strong tNERD (8.23) built on run prevention â elite fielding and enough bats â and, at 86-62, sits atop the AL East with No. 1 seed aspirations. Baltimoreâs tNERD (3.27) drags, and todayâs likely opener Albert SuÃ¡rez is fresh off the IL and short stints, setting up a true bullpen game after Yennier Canoâs latest ninth-inning stumble. Add the immediate narrative heat â Toronto walked off the Oâs last night â and you get a watch with both quality (Bieber) and chaos (Baltimoreâs relief corps).

Tampa Bay Rays @ Chicago Cubs, 11:20a

Summary

Two solid-but-not-sensational starters, plenty of action elsewhere: this gNERD 12.48 lands in the upper third of todayâs slate and around the historic 75th percentile because the teams themselves drive the watchability. Imanaga is chasing a run of consecutive quality starts while the Rays have quietly stacked wins behind Houser, which gives this matchup narrative juice beyond the middling pNERDs.

The pitching profiles say âballs in playâ: Houserâs near-league-average xFIP- (100) with pace and average velo meets Imanagaâs command-forward line (high strike% but a 110 xFIP-), so whiffs may be scarce and gloves busy. The Cubsâ tNERD is doing the heavy liftingâabove-average bats, plus baserunning and elite defenseâwhile Tampa Bay counters with top-tier baserunning and a sturdier bullpen than glove work, which should keep late innings tense. Relative to todayâs average gNERD (10.45), this is a clear cut above without reaching must-watch heights.

Storyline sprinkles: Chicagoâs offense has cooled lately, trimming the margin for error, even as Imanagaâs QS streak continues; Houser enters on a team five-start win run, a reminder that Tampa Bay often finds ways late. Expect crisp tempo, plenty of baserunning pressure, and a defense-versus-contact showcase with just enough pitcher intrigue to keep you parked.

Cincinnati Reds @ Athletics, 1:05p

Summary

Power vs. polish in a powder keg: 22-year-old Luis Morales is pumping 97â99 with early success, while Nick Lodoloâs command-and-curveball game travelsâand both must survive Sacramentoâs cozy confines. With a gNERD of 11.62 (above todayâs average), youâre getting legit stuff plus a ballpark that turns small misses into souvenirs.

Lodoloâs pNERD (6.07) is buoyed by a strong xFIP- (90) and a recent scoreless start as he settles back in after an early-August blister IL stint; his efficiency and grounder tilt fit the assignment. If youâre here for bats, temper expectations: both lineups are light on barrels, and Chicagoâs offense has been getting on without cashing in. Still, the novelty of Cecconiâs midyear emergence and GÃ³mezâs extended look adds some scouting value, and Clevelandâs gloves plus late-inning machine give this a tidy, efficient watch rather than a slugfest.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 13, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

St. Louis Cardinals @ Milwaukee Brewers, 5:15p

Summary

Todayâs top gNERD pits Jacob Misiorowskiâs searing stuff against Sonny Grayâs craft, with Milwaukeeâs chaos-on-the-bases and airtight bullpen tilting the stage. If youâre choosing one game, itâs the power rookie versus the savvy run-suppressor, with real stakes attached.

Misiorowski (pNERD 10.91) is appointment viewing: the 6-foot-7 righty pairs elite extension with triple-digit life, producing Statcast-leading perceived velocities of roughly 101 mph on the fastball and 97 on the sliderâand he opened his career by no-hitting St. Louis for five before a precautionary exit. Gray (pNERD 6.92) remains a worthy foil, carrying an xFIP- around 77âcomfortably better than leagueâwhile living in the zone enough to let the Cardinalsâ plus defense and bullpen share the work. Milwaukeeâs hefty tNERD (9.85) comes from run-prevention theater: high-end baserunning, gloves, and a deep pen that manufactures pressure even without gaudy barrels. Context helps: this gameâs 16.24 gNERD leads todayâs slate and sits above the 95th percentile historically, so the watchability ceiling is real. And the storyline juice is freshâMilwaukee just became MLBâs first to 90 wins and keeps pressing, while St. Louis, now without defensive keystone Masyn Winn, needs Gray to thread a narrow path.

Texas Rangers @ New York Mets, 1:10p

Summary

Rookie vs. wily vet is the hook: Brandon Sproatâs big-velocity, five-pitch audition meets Patrick Corbinâs guile-and-contact routine. With a gNERD of 13.32âwell above todayâs averageâand the Metsâ tNERD leading the slate, this grades as one of the more watchable options.

Sproat just debuted with six innings, seven strikeouts, and a no-hit bid into the sixth; the arsenal is upper-90s heat plus a firm change and sweeper, though command can wander, which is exactly the sort of volatility that makes for good TV. Corbin arrives with an average-ish run estimator (xFIP- ~99 by our inputs) and little swing-and-miss, a veteran innings plug the Rangers signed to steady a rotation thinned by injuries. The entertainment balance tilts toward the Metsâ bats and broadcastâtop-of-the-day tNERD built on barrels and run creationâwhile Texas contributes crisp defense and live legs. Meanwhile, New Yorkâs rotation churn (Senga rehabbing, Jonah Tongâs spot in question) keeps the Sproat subplot spicy. If you needed a narrative nudge, even deGromâs homecoming opener set the stage for this series.

Tampa Bay Rays @ Chicago Cubs, 11:20a

Summary

This checks a lot of watchability boxes: a gNERD of 12.93 (top-quartile historically and above todayâs average) plus two of MLBâs most larcenous clubs on the bases and a crisp Rasmussen-versus-contact matchup. Add a Rizzo celebration at Wrigley and Nico Hoerner riding a hit streak, and youâve got narrative garnish to the numbers.

Drew Rasmussenâs pNERD (6.39) is buoyed by an 87 xFIP- and midâ90s heat, and the results have followed: five scoreless in his last outing and a season line with a subâ1.00 WHIP; heâs also been stingy on barrels for weeks, which matters more than ERA here. Colin Reaâs lower pNERD (2.33) reflects fewer whiffs (K ~18% and 98 K in 136 IP), but he can lean on one of 2025âs better team defenses to turn balls in play into outs. The entertainment engine, though, is the team side: Cubs tNERD is robust (10.35) thanks to plus bats and gloves, while Tampa Bayâs 6.79 is goosed by elite speed. Expect actionâRays lead MLB in steals and the Cubs arenât far behind, by both steals and baserunning value. With Chicagoâs closer Daniel Palencia on the IL and saves lately shared, the late innings could get weirdâin a good way for neutral viewers.

New York Yankees @ Boston Red Sox, 1:10p

Max Friedâs stronger underlying run prevention (xFIP- 84) meets Brayan Bello, the Yankee-tamer whoâs already strung 14 scoreless innings against them this year; the mound duel is the hook. Pair New Yorkâs elite barrels with Bostonâs gloves-and-bullpen edge, and you get watchability by design, not accident.

This gameâs gNERD is 12.87âwell above todayâs 10.89 averageâbecause both teams rate highly (tNERD: NYY 8.01, BOS 8.87) while the starters land around average (pNERD: Fried 5.08, Bello 3.77). The appeal is contrast: the Yankees crush the ball (barrel-rate component +2.52; batting runs +1.74), while Boston brings slick defense and a sturdy relief corps (fielding +1.25, bullpen +1.44). Fried arrives on a heater and even blanked Boston for six on Aug. 22, but Bello has already outdueled him twice.

Recent context helps: New York just won 4â1 at Fenway behind six no-hit innings from Luis Gil and another Aaron Judge moonshot, nudging the Yankees ahead in a tight wild-card race; late leads now funnel to Devin Williams and David Bednar. Boston, meanwhile, has leaned on Belloâs power sinker/velo profile despite middling whiffs. Also note Anthony Volpeâs shoulder has him sitting, trimming New Yorkâs infield offense.

Greeneâs 12.41 pNERD is the headliner, powered by upperâ90s gas and swingâandâmiss, plus a tidy 3.20 FIP and a recent 12âstrikeout, oneâhit gem that reminded everyone why heâs appointment viewing; his K/BB has also sat in ace territory. Severino, meanwhile, brings a middling FIP (~4.05) and the leagueâs most conspicuous Jekyll/Hyde act: solid on the road but bruised at Sutter Health Park, where his run prevention has lagged badly. Team-wise, the Aâs carry the livelier tNERD (7.12) with contact/OBP that keeps innings noisy, and they opened the set with a win, so thereâs spoiler spice even if their defense and pen wobble. Webb owns the nightâs pitching intrigue: a high pNERD (9.49) backed by improved strike and whiff rates without sacrificing his elite ground-ball profile, and he just crossed the 200-strikeout milestone this week. That combination keeps contact tame and innings efficient. Add a fresh chapterâyesterdayâs extra-inning gut punch courtesy of Patrick Baileyâand the atmosphere is playoff-adjacent without the breathlessness. Expect Webbâs run-prevention skills to define the pace, Kershawâs guile to test the edges, and every baserunning decision to feel oversized. Also: reports have Kershaw lined up to oppose Webb here.

Colorado Rockies @ San Diego Padres, 5:40p

Summary

If youâre here for strikeouts and a milestone chase, Dylan Cease trying to clear 1,000 career innings with San Diegoâs MLBâbest bullpen behind him is your draw; if youâre here for a duel, temper expectations. Colorado did just snap its Petco Park lull with Blaine Crimâs first MLB homer, and the Padresâ slim division/WC margin keeps this âshould winâ from feeling entirely preordained.

With a gNERD of 7.16ânear the floor of todayâs slateâthe split is obvious: Padresâ solid tNERD (buoyed by a topâtier âpen) versus a Rockies tNERD dragged down by light bats, sloppy baserunning, and a leaky bullpen. San Diegoâs watchability rests on Ceaseâs pNERD (7.5) and batâmissing stuff; the righty has continued to pile up punchouts and sits five outs from that roundânumber innings mark. Colorado recalls Bradley Blalock to patch the rotation; projections peg a short leash and his earlier thrashing by these Padres (12 runs in 3.2 IP) hardly boosts the pregame intrigue. If the Padres get even a modest lead, their bullpenâbestâinâclass by ERA latelyâcan turn this into cruise control. The Rockiesâ surprise win last game proves weirdness is possible, but the entertainment case here is mostly Cease, the chase, and whether San Diego stabilizes after a stumble while sitting 2.5 back in the West.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 12, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Texas Rangers @ New York Mets, 4:10p

Summary

Jacob deGrom returning to Queens to face the franchise he defined is reason enough; the model agrees, tagging this as todayâs top watch with a gNERD that sits above the 95th percentile of historical games. Across from him is rookie volatility in Jonah Tong, a strikeout prodigy still being introduced to major-league bats. DeGromâs first start against the Mets at Citi Field adds real narrative juice, and heâs looked plenty ace-like in 2025, even earning an All-Star nod; our pNERD loves his power/command profile (xFIP- 77, upper-90s velo). Tong, meanwhile, is the Metsâ No. 4 prospect and MiLBâs K leader this year, now making his third career start after punching out 12 in his first 11 big-league inningsâan ideal âunknown upsideâ companion to deGromâs known excellence. The Mets arrive on a six-game skid, which doesnât predict outcomes but does heighten stakes, while their tNERD-leading offense ensures any mistake gets punished. Add in a lineup featuring Soto with Alonso and Lindor to test the kid, plus Texasâ clean baserunning/defense, and youâve got elite stuff versus fresh chaosâexcellent television.

Detroit Tigers @ Miami Marlins, 4:10p

Summary

Ace-on-ace with a twist: Tarik Skubalâs Cy Young-caliber buzzsaw meets Sandy Alcantaraâs postâTommy John revival. Detroitâs magic number is eight, so one dugout has stakes while the other has a former Cy winner trending up enough to play spoiler.

At a gNERD of 15.91, this lands near todayâs ceiling and above the 95th percentile of historical games, and the reasons line up: Skubalâs massive pNERD (13.56) reflects elite underlying run prevention (xFIP- 61) and upper-90s heat, and heâs held foes to one earned run or fewer in four straight. Alcantaraâs pNERD trails, but heâs stacked quality starts in four of his last five and the velocity is back in the upper 90s, hinting at a real rebound. Detroitâs higher tNERD (7.71) signals a watchable mix of barrels and baserunning, while Miamiâs lighter bats (lower tNERD) make this more about whether Alcantara can match zeroes with Skubal. Bullpens on both sides grade as soft spots, nudging the drama either toward a crisp duel early or frayed nerves late if the starters exit. And if you like narrative juice, Skubalâs encore season has looked even sharper than his 2024 Cy run, putting him squarely in repeat territory.

Tampa Bay Rays @ Chicago Cubs, 11:20a

Summary

High gNERD, real juice: Matthew Boyd has been a Wrigley cheat code, while Tampa counters with 97-mph Shane Baz and a bullpen that keeps games tight. Two top-tier tNERD teamsâCubs for defense/baserunning, Rays for speedâmake this a watchable, run-precarious tilt.

gNERD 14.35 sits near the top both historically and for today, driven by Chicagoâs big tNERD (elite barrels, fielding, and legs) versus a Rays club that runs well and leans on a deep pen. Bazâs pNERD edge (6.76 to 4.92) reflects the stuff: upper-90s heat and a curve thatâs been a featured weapon; he also comes in off 5 innings/2 runs last time out. Boyd narrows that gap with command and an NLâtopâ10 FIP profile, and heâs been nearly untouchable at home this year. Recent color favors the Cubs: the bullpen is humming even with closer Daniel Palencia on the IL, and theyâre fresh off locking down the Braves twice. Tampaâs offense is volatile but dangerous on the basesârookie Chandler Simpson already hit 40 stealsâso any Boyd mistake can turn into instant chaos.

St. Louis Cardinals @ Milwaukee Brewers, 5:10p

Summary

Speed, gloves, and a hot hand: Milwaukeeâs track-meet Brewers plus Quinn Priesterâs recent heater make this a high-upside watch, and the 12.31 gNERD says itâs one of todayâs better bets. St. Louis counters with elite leather and Andre Pallanteâs ground-ball tilt, so expect action on contact rather than a strikeout clinic.

Priester owns the stronger pNERD (6.29) and lately the outcomes to match â seven sturdy innings in his last start and an 11-decision win streak amid a 17-game Brewers run when he pitches â after arriving in April to bolster an injury-thinned staff, and he works quickly (pace helps the watchability). Milwaukeeâs league-leading tNERD (9.82) reflects run-and-catch baseball thatâs been a 2025 calling card, even with bullpen dings like Nick Mears; Abner Uribe has helped cover late. The Cardinalsâ middling tNERD (4.82) is propped up by best-in-class defense, and they just got Alec Burleson back to fortify a light offense. Pallanteâs pNERD (3.70) fits the profile â playable xFIP, sinker-heavy grounders, few whiffs â though he did spin seven scoreless recently, which keeps the floor watchable. If you like balls in play, aggressive running, and a starter on a roll, this checks the boxes.

Baltimore Orioles @ Toronto Blue Jays, 4:07p

Summary

A genuine watchability cocktail: Trevor Rogersâ strike-flooding breakout (roughly a 2.4â2.6 FIP with 56% zone rate and 66% first-pitch strikes) runs headlong into a first-place club and a playoff-loud Rogers Centre. Toronto answers with Chris Bassittâs kitchen-sink and elite team defense, but Baltimore has lately been the pebble in contendersâ shoes.

At a gNERD 11.91, this sits comfortably above todayâs average, and the âwhyâ tracks: a high-pNERD arm (Rogers 8.36) versus a high-tNERD team (Jays 7.95). Rogersâ xFIP- of 81 and strike-throwing binge make him appointment viewing; Bassittâs xFIP- of 91 is steadier, though his deliberate pace dings aesthetics. Torontoâs tNERD is buoyed by strong fielding and real bats, and the atmosphere just got a fresh jolt after Kevin Gausmanâs two-hit shutout and a series win over Houston. Baltimore, meanwhile, arrives off a sweep and a staff thatâs been stingy this month, with the season series in their favor (6â4) and the recent âspoilerâ vibe fully engaged. Bassittâs results against the Oâs havenât been great historically, tilting the pitching intrigue toward Rogersâ reinvented version. If you want one clean narrative: watch whether Rogersâ in-zone aggression and weak-contact profile can survive Torontoâs contact and gloves in a pennant-race building.

Los Angeles Dodgers @ San Francisco Giants, 7:15p

One out from a no-hitter meets one rung up the strikeout ladder: Yamamotoâs peak form versus Verlanderâs livingâlegend craft in a rivalry with real October leverage. At a gNERD of 11.65âabove todayâs 10.71 average and brushing the historic 75th percentileâthis deserves priority.

pNERD tilts toward Yoshinobu Yamamoto (8.66): a 75 xFIP- and midâ90s velocity back batâmissing stuff, fresh off that 8ââinning near noâno in Baltimore. Justin Verlanderâs pNERD (3.38) and 107 xFIP- say âuneven,â yet he just fired six scoreless and moved past Gaylord Perry on the allâtime K list, which keeps the curiosity switch on. Team-wise, the Dodgersâ tNERD (7.19) leans on loud contact and a sturdy bullpen, and the lineup is hummingâMookie Betts just posted 13 RBIs in five games, with reinforcements returning. The Giantsâ tNERD (4.07) lags thanks to light barrels and baserunning, but Rafael Devers and Willy Adames have been carrying real thump lately. Stakes help: seven headâtoâheads remain, with LA up three in the West and San Francisco within striking distance of a wild card. In short, come for Yamamotoâs splitter against a warming Giants order, stay to see whether Verlanderâs chess game can steal one.

New York Yankees @ Boston Red Sox, 4:10p

Summary

Two heavy-hitting, high-tNERD clubs in a pennant race beat a low-pNERD matchup every time; this oneâs about lineups, defense, and late innings more than the opening act. With the Yankees nudging ahead of Boston in a tight wild-card scrum and Aaron Judge teeing off again, the rivalry has real stakes and plenty of thump.

Luis Gilâs pNERD is light, and his profile still leans âlive arm, uncertain command,â which tracks after a spring lat strain and last yearâs walk issues; heâs back now but hasnât built the same workload as his counterpart. entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 11, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

New York Mets @ Philadelphia Phillies, 4:15p

Summary

Two attacking lefties with whiffs and pace headline a topâtier watchability matchup: JesÃºs Luzardoâs power mix against a Mets lineup that barrels everything. Philadelphiaâs left side is patched together â Trea Turner and Alec Bohm are on the IL â so Bryce Harper is leading off, which adds both novelty and volatility.

The gNERD is skyâhigh because both components pop: Mets tNERD is elite (10.6% barrel rate, strong batting runs), while the Phillies bring speed and gloves but a thinner offense without Turner/Bohm. Luzardo carries the higher pNERD, driven by plus velo and whiffs, and he just punched out eight over six in Miami; his sweeper/slider combo has looked back to form since arriving via the offseason trade. David Petersonâs pNERD trails but still signals competence (xFIP- in the highâ80s, quick tempo), giving this a legitimate âbothâsidesâ feel rather than ace-vs.-overmatch. The scheduled pairing is Peterson vs. Luzardo, with the divisionâleading Phillies trying to protect a multipleâgame cushion on New York.

Net: watch for Luzardoâs velocity and whiffs against a highâbarrel Mets order, and whether Harperâs turn at the top can compensate for Phillyâs missing infield anchors.

Detroit Tigers @ New York Yankees, 4:05p

Summary

A 100-mph rookie against an opener and two barrel-happy lineups is already fun; add Detroit thumping New York by a combined 23â3 the last two games, and the simmer is unmistakable. With a gNERD of 15.05âtop ~5% in our historical sampleâthis profiles as one of the dayâs better watches.

Cam Schlittler brings the novelty: his debut averaged 97.9 mph and touched 100, the fastest heater by a Yankees starter this season, and heâs held a rotation spot since, making him the âstuffâ headliner here. Tyler Holton is the counter: Detroit has used him as an opener repeatedly, which usually means a quick look at a lefty before handing off to bulk inningsâwatchable strategy, even if it caps pNERD-style dominance.

The NERD bits back it up: both teams carry above-average tNERDs (DET 7.73, NYY 7.87) with plus barrel rates, while the pitchersâ xFIP components (Holton 87-, Schlittler 90-) hint at real strike-zone competence without turning this into a slog. And thereâs fresh storyline juice: Detroit just routed New York in consecutive games, with late-inning homer barrages and the Yankeesâ offense scuffling into double plays.

Tampa Bay Rays @ Chicago White Sox, 11:10a

Summary

Two rookie-ish riddles on one mound: Rays lefty Ian Seymourâs bat-missing, quick-tempo profile meets the White Soxâs Rule 5 revelation Shane Smith, who burst onto the scene and even earned an All-Star nod. Add in Junior Camineroâs 40-homer thunder and Tampa Bayâs run-making chaos on the bases, and this one has sneaky morning-coffee appeal.

gNERD puts this solidly above todayâs average, and the ingredients make sense: Seymour (pNERD 8.70) brings a strong run estimator (xFIP- 77), strikeout chops, and a brisk pace that keeps the camera busy; Smith (pNERD 4.77) offers midâ90s velocity and a developing mix but a league-worse-ish xFIP- (106) that can turn contact into traffic. Tampa Bayâs tNERD edge (6.91 to 2.96) shows up in the how-they-score department: the Raysâ MLBâleading steal count pressures a Sox defense thatâs leaked runs all year, a contrast tailorâmade for watchability. If you like emergingâarm matchups, Seymourâs first-start blueprintâfive scoreless with eight Ksâsuggests upside, while Smithâs early-season run from âRule 5 curiosityâ to rotation piece supplied real theater. And if you just want dingers, Camineroâs 42nd was a fresh reminder that any Rays plate appearance can flip an inning.

Washington Nationals @ Miami Marlins, 3:40p

Summary

Two quality lefties on (likely) short leashes make this more pitcher-watchable than team-watchable. And after a messy, ejection-filled inning last game, thereâs just enough spice to keep the remote parked here. With a gNERD of 9.88, this sits a touch below todayâs average, but the arms lift it: pNERD average 6.73 beats todayâs pitcher mean. MacKenzie Gore returns from the IL with above-average swing-and-miss and a tidy xFIP- (90 in the inputs), the sort of peripherals that have outpaced his surface line; Washington reportedly planned to activate him for the finale after a shoulder IL stint. Ryan Weathers, meanwhile, is being activated from the 60-day IL to start, likely with a workload cap; his spring jump to a 97-ish fastball added some intrigue before the lat detour. If you prefer clean baseball, beware: the Nationalsâ defense rates poorly in our inputs and also imploded in that sixth-inning fiasco, while Miamiâs bullpen grades shaky. The bats donât helpâboth clubs carry below-average tNERDsâso the draw is Goreâs bat-missing and Weathersâ stuff/velocity versus light lineups. Miami did snap a five-game skid against Washington last game, but thatâs color, not cause.

Kansas City Royals @ Cleveland Guardians, 4:15p

Summary

Hard-throwing intrigue meets glove-first grind: Gavin Williamsâ premium heat and Clevelandâs elite run prevention butt heads with two of MLBâs quieter lineups, so bring your appreciation for leather and late-inning leverage. Kansas Cityâs rotation shuffle puts more weight on a good bullpen, making this a tidy, tense watch rather than a slugfest.

With a gNERD of 9.45, this sits a touch below todayâs average, but the ingredients are solid: Williamsâ pNERD (5.29) is buoyed by upperâ90s velocity that has brushed triple digits and recently carried him within two outs of ending the Guardiansâ 44âyear noâno drought, while Stephen Kolekâs lower pNERD (3.20) and modest whiff profile point to balls in play for Kansas Cityâs gloves to decide.

Team-wise, the model is honest: Clevelandâs higher tNERD (6.11) rides defense and bullpen value, while both clubsâ bats have laggedâCleveland near the bottom in average and runs, Kansas City similarly run-starvedâso the watchability here leans on crisp pace and prevention more than fireworks.

Thereâs real context, too: both clubs remain on the fringes of the Wild Card mix, and Kansas City has been patching the rotation after Michael Wachaâs concussion IL stint, raising the odds of early highâleverage bullpen cameos.

Houston Astros @ Toronto Blue Jays, 12:07p

Summary

A deft defense-versus-uncertainty watch: Torontoâs glove work flanks Kevin Gausman, while Houston hands the ball to Cristian Javier still in the shallow end of a postâTommy John return. The gNERD sits a bit below todayâs average because the pitching half lags, but both clubsâ strong team profiles keep it viable TV.

Gausmanâs pNERD edge (5.46) pairs with a betterâthanâaverage xFIP and strike throwing, and his contact management plays to whatâs been an elite Blue Jays defense this season. Javierâs the swing factor: this is just his sixth start back from surgery, with one gem mixed among bouts of shaky command, including a stumble versus New York. If youâre tuning for tactics, watch how Torontoâs hittersâone of the secondâhalfâs better unitsâlay off elevated heaters to force Javier into the zone.

The model likes the teams (both tNERDs above todayâs mean), especially Torontoâs run prevention and Houstonâs bullpen on paper, but the Astrosâ lateâinning picture is frayed: Josh Haderâs out, Bryan Abreu is carrying the ninth, and usage has been heavy. The series context helps, tooâHouston is coming off a 3â2 win on a Yainer DÃ­az ninthâinning homerâwhich adds just enough spice to an otherwise pitcherâtilted afternoon.

Sorianoâs profile (8.16 pNERD, plus velocity and a sharp sinker/curve mix) fits the eye testâheâs shown ace flashes this yearâeven if his last outing was a clunker (8 ER vs. OAK), the volatility that makes him compelling. With a gNERD of 7.82, this sits below todayâs average, but thereâs texture: Cade Povich carries the better pNERD (5.45) and a legitimately solid xFIP- (93), with a league-average-ish FIP (4.28) underpinning the profile; he just returned from a hip IL stint and is lined up here after a win that still featured a bumpy sixth. The Oriolesâ recent habit of walk-offs and cameos from youngsters like Jackson Holliday and Dylan Beavers nudge watchability upward even if the offense has lagged overall. On the other side, Oviedoâs velo (95.3) and comeback tale are more compelling than his 107 xFIP-, but he did notch a five-inning, six-K, one-run win in his second start back. Pirates bats grade poorly by our numbers, though their defense and bullpen are serviceable; Baltimoreâs pen has under-shot season-long metrics yet has delivered in these tight finishes.

entry.content:

Detail

New York Mets @ Philadelphia Phillies, 3:45p

Summary

Top watchability alert: a gNERD 16.66 pits the Metsâ bat-mashing, high-tNERD offense against Cristopher SÃ¡nchezâs ace-level craft, while New Yorkâs great experimentâClay Holmes, starterâtries to hold serve. If you enjoy elite contact quality squaring off with an elite out pitch, clear a screen.

SÃ¡nchez brings a pNERD 9.47 with a sub-70 xFIP- and one of baseballâs nastiest changeups, a pitch thatâs drawn Cy talk and routinely shreds bats; heâs been rolling of late, too. Holmes vs. SÃ¡nchez is indeed the matchup, and itâs a study in contrasts: the Phillies lefty yields few barrels, while Holmesâ conversion from Yankees closer to Mets starterâhe was even tabbed as Opening Day starterâhas settled into âadequate,â but with recent red flags (walks/homers up, ~5.2 FIP over a six-start slice).

The team-side engine drives the gNERD: Mets tNERD 12.23 (barrels, offense, bullpen depth) versus Phillies 8.76 (plus baserunning), and Phillyâs lineup is hummingâKyle Schwarber just reached 50 homers. Add in Mets rotation attrition (e.g., Frankie Montas headed for Tommy John), and thereâs plenty of intrigue without invoking âmomentum.â

Tampa Bay Rays @ Chicago White Sox, 4:40p

Summary

A top-tier gNERD and Tampa Bayâs playoff urgency make this one highly watchable: an elite pNERD arm in Griffin Jax meets an injury-thinned White Sox lineup, with the Raysâ speed and bullpen poised to matter late. Tampa Bay is hovering four games back in the AL wild-card chase, adding real stakes to every lever Kevin Cash can pull.

The model loves Jax (pNERD 14.04), and for good reason: his pitch mix has produced top-10 strikeout and whiff rates among relievers, underpinned by an xFIP- around 49 and upper-90s heat; whether he opens or slams the door, thatâs bat-missing you can plan evening around. Tampa Bayâs tNERD (6.79) leans on elite baserunning and a strong bullpen, exactly the ingredients that turn close games fun. Chicagoâs tNERD (2.94) drags with poor defense and baserunning, and the lineup still lacks Luis Robert Jr. (hamstring, IL), though youngsters like Colson Montgomery have flashed. Tuesdayâs tight 5-4 Rays win â decided by a late Tristan Gray homer â previewed the script: Sox can hang, but Tampaâs depth (and dingers) tilt the endgame. Historically, a 14.38 gNERD sits near the 95th percentile and is among todayâs best, so if youâre choosing one, pick the one with the nasty sweeper and the track shoes.

Detroit Tigers @ New York Yankees, 4:05p

Summary

Playoff-tinged power vs. pluck: the Yankeesâ barrel-happy lineup meets Detroitâs young, speedy bunch, a day after the Tigers detonated a nine-run inning in the Bronx. With a gNERD of 13.29 that sits near the top of todayâs slate, this grades as must-sample television even without a true ace-on-ace tilt.

Jack Flahertyâs mid-pack pNERD captures the experience: bat-missing stuff but volatility that shows up most against lefties; his 2025 splits feature a higher wOBA allowed to LHB than RHB, the type of profile New York can stress. Keep an eye on how quickly A.J. Hinch pulls him the third time through. Carlos RodÃ³n, meanwhile, rolls in on a five-start win streak and has smothered bats at Yankee Stadium, including a sub-.240 wOBA allowed at home and to lefties. Thatâs the kind of underlying dominance that plays even when the Kâs arenât spiking.

Narrative fuel isnât lacking: Aaron Judge returned from an elbow scare and promptly leapfrogged Yogi Berra on the franchise homer list, while ex-Yankee Gleyber Torres is now drawing ovations in road gray. Also, Detroit just widened its cushion atop the AL Central as New York jockeys for position.

Summary

Chris Saleâs return-from-IL whiff machine meets the Cubsâ brand of joyful disorderâspeed, defense, and loud contactâwhich is a pretty good way to spend a game window. At gNERD 13.0, this sits above todayâs average and around the historic upper quartile, driven by Saleâs strong pNERD (8.41) and a Cubs tNERD (10.14) that screams entertainment.

Sale just came back from a rib fracture and struck out nine over six crisp innings in his activation start, a reminder that his bat-missing slider/change mix still plays; Atlantaâs rotation attrition only sharpens the spotlight on him. Chicagoâs listed starter was TBD, but indications had rookie Cade Horton lining up opposite Sale; Horton recently muzzled Atlanta for 6â innings of one-run ball, adding intrigue to the rematch angle. The watchability tilt favors the Cubsâ style: elite defense and plus baserunning feed long, eventful innings, while Atlantaâs weaker baserunning and bullpen dampen their tNERD. Meanwhile, Chicago is missing All-Star Kyle Tucker (calf), a notable bat subtracted from the card. If Saleâs xFIP- (75 in the inputs) holds and Horton again suppresses hard contact, you get a high-strikeout, low-walk chess match spiced by Cubs chaos on the basepathsâenough substance to justify its top-tier gNERD.
